automating your business.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://exa.ai/blog/exa-api-2-0\">Exa Fast and Deep</a> - Two new search API for your AI products.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://docs.n8n.io/release-notes/#ai-workflow-builder-beta\">AI workflow builder by n8n</a> - Build workflows, nodes and structure from your prompts in English.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://x.com/0interestrates/status/1977788884298903773\">Julius AI</a> now connects to your SQL Server and writes SQL for you to analyse performance, adoption and other KPIs.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://blog.google/technology/google-labs/video-overviews-nano-banana\">NotebookLM&#8217;s</a> video overviews can now use images generated by Nano-Banana and a shorter format called Brief.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://yc-unicorn-predictor.vercel.app/\">YC unicorn predictor</a> - Are you making something people want? (I think the biggest change to YC&#8217;s tagline in the future will be &#8216;Make something agents want&#8217;)</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><h3> &#129379; Dev dish</h3><ul><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/karpathy/nanochat\">nanochat</a> - A minimal repo from Karpathy to train an LLM from scratch, and then take it through post-training with SFT, RL and run it in a ChatGPT like interface. (<a href=\"https://x.com/karpathy/status/1977755427569111362\">discussions on X</a>)</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/midday-ai/ai-sdk-tools\">ai-sdk-tools</a> - Essential utilities for building production-ready AI applications.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/steveyegge/beads\">Beads</a> - A drop-in cognitive upgrade for your coding agent of choice. (<a href=\"https://steve-yegge.medium.com/introducing-beads-a-coding-agent-memory-system-637d7d92514a\">read more</a>)</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><h3> &#127846; Afters</h3><ul><li><p>Dwarkesh Patel and Stripe Press have a new book, <a href=\"https://x.com/dwarkesh_sp/status/1975958555313504324\">The Scaling Era: An Oral History of AI 2019-2025</a>.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://huggingface.co/LiquidAI/LFM2-350M-PII-Extract-JP\">This 350M params model from Liquid AI</a> performs similarly to GPT-5 when extracting PII from Japanese texts.</p></li><li><p>new research: you can just ask an LLM if a certain demographic would <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/2510.08338\">purchase your product</a> and get reliable answers.</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><div class=\"captioned-button-wrap\" data-attrs=\"{&quot;url&quot;:&quot;https://www.bensbites.com/p/recipes-for-claude-maxxing?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&action=share&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Share&quot;}\" data-component-name=\"CaptionedButtonToDOM\"><div class=\"preamble\"><p class=\"cta-caption\">Enjoy this newsletter? Forward it to a friend.</p></div><p class=\"button-wrapper\" data-attrs=\"{&quot;url&quot;:&quot;https://www.bensbites.com/p/recipes-for-claude-maxxing?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&action=share&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Share&quot;}\" data-component-name=\"ButtonCreateButton\"><a class=\"button primary\" href=\"https://www.bensbites.com/p/recipes-for-claude-maxxing?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&action=share\"><span>Share</span></a></p></div><p>That&#8217;s it for today. Feel free to comment and share your thoughts. &#128075;</p><ul><li><p>Find me on <a href=\"https://x.com/bentossell/\">X</a>, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ben-tossell-70453537/\">Linkedin</a>, or <a href=\"https://instagram.com/bentossell\">Instagram</a></p></li><li><p>Read <a href=\"https://bensbites.substack.com/about\">about me</a> and ben&#8217;s bites</p></li><li><p>&#128247; thumbnail creds: <a href=\"https://x.com/Keshavatearth\">@keshavatearth</a>,</p></li></ul><h6><em>* marks sponsors that make this newsletter possible :)</em></h6><h6><em>Wanna <a href=\"https://sponsor.bensbites.co/\">partner with us</a>? Last few slots left for the rest of the year.</em></h6><div><hr></div>","content:encodedSnippet":"The newsletter for the technically curious. Updates, tool reviews, and lay of the land from an exited founder turned investor and forever tinkerer.\nSubscribe now\n\n\nHey folks,\nYou can now share your Claude Code setup with others using ‚ÄúClaude Code Plugins‚Äù. Plugins combine slash commands, subagents, MCP servers, and hooks that you have set up into a single JSON. You can publish a set of plugins as a marketplace and let your team members or anyone install them.\nI think this is supposed to be cool but I don‚Äôt think it is - for a while people have been sharing their own commands/agents/etc in GitHub repos for others to copy in their workflows. This just feels like a slightly easier way to bulk download them. (It also feels like the days of people selling Notion templates).\nAnd because so many CLI tools are built similarly, these can just be ported across to any CLI you use. It didn‚Äôt take long for Ian Nuttall to create this, which lets you easily install as bundles or individually from marketplaces into any CLI.\nWhat I do think is cool is reading the different docs people create to enhance their coding workflows. If you‚Äôre paying attention, the files are often just really clear instructions for an agentic tool to follow. I‚Äôm again finding myself trying to code a tool only to end up with a simple markdown file that gives explicit instructions to an agent to follow instead. Apps are specs. \nGemini CLI also launched Gemini Extensions, which package custom commands, MCP servers and specific files into a single JSON config. (again, see Ian‚Äôs tool to easily port into any CLI)\nOpenAI is aggressively ramping up where it gets compute from‚Äîincluding deals with Google Cloud, Nvidia, AMD and now, chips designed by OpenAI itself in partnership with Broadcom. They‚Äôve been working together for 18 months already, and will start deploying 10 GW of compute late next year.\nSlack‚Äôs new platform gives AI agents secure, real-time access to team conversations via RTS (real-time search API) and MCP, enabling context-aware workflows. Launch partners like OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Perplexity, Dropbox, and Notion have built new Slack-native apps.\nClarify is the autonomous CRM that runs itself. It logs calls, enriches contacts, and updates deals‚Äîso you can focus on selling, not systems. Built for fast-moving GTM teams who hate admin work. ‚ö° Start for free.*\n\nEver wonder how this newsletter gets made? Shanice shared what goes on in a day in the life of Ben‚Äôs Bites.\n\n\n üåê What I‚Äôm consuming\n\nAI memory explained: SuperMemory MCP for Cursor, Claude & Windsurf.\n\nWhy everyone will be talking about Harness Engineering in six months.\n\nTechnological Optimism and Appropriate Fear - What do we do if AI progress keeps happening?\n\nThe case for Supermemory is the case for solo founders.\n\nHow Codex ran OpenAI DevDay 2025.\n\nDevRel is unbelievably back. I saved this then surprisingly saw my name mentioned in the post (ty swyx!) - I think dev rel is the best job, especially in today‚Äôs world. A lot of the functions are really similar to being a founder; you speak to your customers every day, listen to & implement feedback, understand your product inside and out, know whats on the roadmap, why certain technical decisions are made and you‚Äôve got to be in charge of growth. I‚Äôm going to start talking about little tools I‚Äôm making to help me in my day to day at Factory, like;\n\nask-factory - i have the full codebase and our docs on my computer (they get auto-updated from github every hour). So when a user asks a technical question or ‚Äòis this workflow possible‚Äô I can query this tool and it‚Äôll look up the code and docs plus linear issues on whether something is already down as a bug or new feature on the roadmap.\n\nlinear-cli - this is just a simple cli tool that uses my linear api key and searches linear. \n\nrelease-notes - this is a way to generate release notes from our latest releases for our changelog (still in progress!)\n\nThese tools aren‚Äôt really tools at all‚Ä¶ they are instruction documents. e.g. ask-factory has instructions to say, look at the factory codebase repo and docs (linking them), then run search queries in parallel across both to get an understanding of which areas the query relates to, then check linear to see if anything relevant in there, then put together in an answer format like '[example]‚Äô. Because when you use an agentic tool like Droid, Claude Code, Codex etc, they can follow instructions really well and have their own tools at their disposal. Fwiw I get way better results currently using gpt-5-codex. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n‚öôÔ∏è  Tools and demos\n\nTasklet - An AI agent for automating your business.\n\nExa Fast and Deep - Two new search API for your AI products.\n\nAI workflow builder by n8n - Build workflows, nodes and structure from your prompts in English.\n\nJulius AI now connects to your SQL Server and writes SQL for you to analyse performance, adoption and other KPIs.\n\nNotebookLM‚Äôs video overviews can now use images generated by Nano-Banana and a shorter format called Brief.\n\nYC unicorn predictor - Are you making something people want? (I think the biggest change to YC‚Äôs tagline in the future will be ‚ÄòMake something agents want‚Äô)\n\n\n\n ü•£ Dev dish\n\nnanochat - A minimal repo from Karpathy to train an LLM from scratch, and then take it through post-training with SFT, RL and run it in a ChatGPT like interface. (discussions on X)\n\nai-sdk-tools - Essential utilities for building production-ready AI applications.\n\nBeads - A drop-in cognitive upgrade for your coding agent of choice. (read more)\n\n\n\n üç¶ Afters\n\nDwarkesh Patel and Stripe Press have a new book, The Scaling Era: An Oral History of AI 2019-2025.\n\nThis 350M params model from Liquid AI performs similarly to GPT-5 when extracting PII from Japanese texts.\n\nnew research: you can just ask an LLM if a certain demographic would purchase your product and get reliable answers.\n\n\n\n\nEnjoy this newsletter? Last few slots left for the rest of the year.","enclosure":{"url":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/9c63e770-f6de-4f3e-8f95-6f34276dadf5_1184x864.png","length":"0","type":"image/jpeg"},"content":"the best job in this timeline","contentSnippet":"the best job in this timeline","guid":"https://www.bensbites.com/p/recipes-for-claude-maxxing","isoDate":"2025-10-14T13:03:35.000Z","itunes":{}},"pairedItem":{"item":17}},{"json":{"title":"How to see through AI marketing","link":"https://www.bensbites.com/p/how-to-see-through-ai-marketing","pubDate":"Thu, 09 Oct 2025 13:02:54 GMT","content:encoded":"<p><em>The newsletter for the technically curious. Updates, tool reviews, and lay of the land from an exited founder turned investor and forever tinkerer.</em></p><p class=\"button-wrapper\" data-attrs=\"{&quot;url&quot;:&quot;https://www.bensbites.com/subscribe?&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Subscribe now&quot;,&quot;action&quot;:null,&quot;class&quot;:null}\" data-component-name=\"ButtonCreateButton\"><a class=\"button primary\" href=\"https://www.bensbites.com/subscribe?\"><span>Subscribe now</span></a></p><div><hr></div><p>Hey folks,</p><p>I was up late last night in SF at the meet-up I hosted, and it was so awesome to meet and speak to a bunch of you. I&#8217;m saving my full SF thoughts for a post next week.</p><p>In the meantime, Google released a preview of its first <strong><a href=\"https://blog.google/technology/google-deepmind/gemini-computer-use-model/\">computer-use model</a></strong> based on Gemini 2.5, in partnership with <strong><a href=\"https://gemini.browserbase.com/\">Browserbase</a></strong>. It&#8217;s a good model&#8212;it scores decently better than Sonnet 4.5 and much better than OpenAI&#8217;s computer use model on <a href=\"https://www.browserbase.com/blog/evaluating-browser-agents\">benchmarks</a>.</p><p>But benchmarks and evaluations can be misleading, especially if you only go by the official announcement posts. This one is a good example to dig into:</p><ul><li><p>This is a model optimised for browser usage, so it&#8217;s not surprising that it does better than the base version of Sonnet 4.5</p></li><li><p>OpenAI&#8217;s computer use model used in this comparison is 7 months old&#8212;a version based on 4o. (side note: I had high expectations for a new computer use model at Dev Day)</p></li><li><p>The product experience of the model matters. ChatGPT Agent, even with a worse model, feels better because it&#8217;s a good product combining a computer-using model, a browser and a terminal.</p></li></ul><p>I don&#8217;t mean to say that companies do it out of malice. Finding the latest scores and implementation of a benchmark is hard, and you don&#8217;t want to be too nuanced in a marketing post about your launch. But we, as users, need to understand the model cycle and the taste of the dessert being sold to us.</p><p>Even with all these factors, the new Gemini model definitely passes the smoke test.  </p><p>The smoke test is just one way we decide what makes it into every newsletter post and what doesn&#8217;t. Shanice wrote about it in detail in this post, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/day-life-bens-bites-shanice-stewart-jones-8um8c/\">A day in the life of Ben&#8217;s Bites</a>.</p><p>With <strong><a href=\"https://retool.com/?utm_source=bensbites&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=copilot&amp;utm_content=main_ad&amp;rcid=701Qo000014OTm9IAG\">Retool</a></strong>, you can turn prompts into full-stack internal tools&#8212;connected to your data, hosted in your cloud, and secured by your rules. Build easier, deploy safely, and move from idea to production in minutes.*</p><div><hr></div><h3><strong> </strong>&#127760;<strong> </strong>What I&#8217;m consuming</h3><ul><li><p><a href=\"https://www.latent.space/p/figma\">Taste is your moat</a> with Dylan Field, Figma.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://open.spotify.com/show/4O7eFPtxPBSrdsO2KwY6Ko\">Agents of Scale</a> - new podcast by my old boss at Zapier.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://theoatmeal.com/comics/ai_art\">A cartoonist&#8217;s review of AI art</a> by The Oatmeal. </p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/7/vibe-engineering/\">Vibe engineering</a> and embracing the <a href=\"https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/5/parallel-coding-agents/\">parallel coding agent lifestyle</a>.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://stratechery.com/2025/sora-ai-bicycles-and-meta-disruption/\">Sora, AI Bicycles, and Meta Disruption</a>.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://kix.dev/two-things-llm-coding-agents-are-still-bad-at/\">Two things LLM coding agents are still bad at</a>: copy-pasting code and asking questions. This is actually a good critique&#8212;especially the first one. I wonder if you could create an app/service for refactoring codebases by teaching an open-source model (like Kimi K2 or GLM 4.6) to use &#8220;cut/copy/paste&#8221; as tools.</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.stateof.ai/\">The State of AI report 2025</a></strong> &#8212; this one will take me a few days to go through.</p></li></ul><div class=\"captioned-image-container\"><figure><a It feeds performance issues and slow endpoints directly into your AI coding assistant.*</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://aistudio.google.com/apps\">Google AI Studio</a></strong> now lets you &#129379; Dev dish</h3><ul><li><p><a href=\"https://playwright.dev/docs/test-agents\">Playwright</a>, the browser automation library, has agents now. One to plan tests, another to generate them and a healer to debug and fix failing tests.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/joseairosa/recall\">Recall</a> - Redis-powered persistent memory for Claude (usable as an MCP server).</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/Doriandarko/sora-mcp\">sora-mcp</a> - An MCP server to use Sora video generation APIs.</p></li><li><p>You can use any open-source model in <a href=\"https://x.com/FactoryAI/status/1975643644326793619\">Factory AI&#8217;s Droid</a>. </p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://repoprompt.com/bench\">Repobench</a> - Ranking models for large context reasoning, file editing precision, and instruction adherence for coding tasks. I met Eric yesterday and chatted about <a href=\"https://repoprompt.com/blog/building-repo-bench\">how he built this</a>.</p></li></ul><div class=\"captioned-image-container\"><figure><a class=\"image-link image2 is-viewable-img\" target=\"_blank\" valuation.</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><div class=\"captioned-button-wrap\" Updates, tool reviews, and lay of the land from an exited founder turned investor and forever tinkerer.\nSubscribe now\n\n\nHey folks,\nI was up late last night in SF at the meet-up I hosted, and it was so awesome to meet and speak to a bunch of you. I‚Äôm saving my full SF thoughts for a post next week.\nIn the meantime, Google released a preview of its first computer-use model based on Gemini 2.5, in partnership with Browserbase. It‚Äôs a good model‚Äîit scores decently better than Sonnet 4.5 and much better than OpenAI‚Äôs computer use model on benchmarks.\nBut benchmarks and evaluations can be misleading, especially if you only go by the official announcement posts. This one is a good example to dig into:\n\nThis is a model optimised for browser usage, so it‚Äôs not surprising that it does better than the base version of Sonnet 4.5\n\nOpenAI‚Äôs computer use model used in this comparison is 7 months old‚Äîa version based on 4o. (side note: I had high expectations for a new computer use model at Dev Day)\n\nThe product experience of the model matters. ChatGPT Agent, even with a worse model, feels better because it‚Äôs a good product combining a computer-using model, a browser and a terminal.\n\nI don‚Äôt mean to say that companies do it out of malice. Finding the latest scores and implementation of a benchmark is hard, and you don‚Äôt want to be too nuanced in a marketing post about your launch. But we, as users, need to understand the model cycle and the taste of the dessert being sold to us.\nEven with all these factors, the new Gemini model definitely passes the smoke test.  \nThe smoke test is just one way we decide what makes it into every newsletter post and what doesn‚Äôt. Shanice wrote about it in detail in this post, A day in the life of Ben‚Äôs Bites.\nWith Retool, you can turn prompts into full-stack internal tools‚Äîconnected to your data, hosted in your cloud, and secured by your rules. Build easier, deploy safely, and move from idea to production in minutes.*\n\n\n üåê What I‚Äôm consuming\n\nTaste is your moat with Dylan Field, Figma.\n\nAgents of Scale - new podcast by my old boss at Zapier.\n\nA cartoonist‚Äôs review of AI art by The Oatmeal. \n\nVibe engineering and embracing the parallel coding agent lifestyle.\n\nSora, AI Bicycles, and Meta Disruption.\n\nTwo things LLM coding agents are still bad at: copy-pasting code and asking questions. This is actually a good critique‚Äîespecially the first one. I wonder if you could create an app/service for refactoring codebases by teaching an open-source model (like Kimi K2 or GLM 4.6) to use ‚Äúcut/copy/paste‚Äù as tools.\n\nThe State of AI report 2025 ‚Äî this one will take me a few days to go through.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n‚öôÔ∏è  Tools and demos\n\nScout Monitoring‚Äôs MCP - AI-native monitoring. It feeds performance issues and slow endpoints directly into your AI coding assistant.*\n\nGoogle AI Studio now lets you use your voice as an input for vibe coding.\n\nElevenLabs launched Agent Workflows and an open source UI library for building voice agents.\n\nGrok Imagine now uses xAI‚Äôs Imagine 0.9 model with audio generation.\n\nOpal, Google‚Äôs experimental product for chaining AI steps together with a visual builder, is now open globally (with MCP support coming soon).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n ü•£ Dev dish\n\nPlaywright, the browser automation library, has agents now. One to plan tests, another to generate them and a healer to debug and fix failing tests.\n\nRecall - Redis-powered persistent memory for Claude (usable as an MCP server).\n\nsora-mcp - An MCP server to use Sora video generation APIs.\n\nYou can use any open-source model in Factory AI‚Äôs Droid. \n\nRepobench - Ranking models for large context reasoning, file editing precision, and instruction adherence for coding tasks. I met Eric yesterday and chatted about how he built this.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n üç¶ Afters\n\nAgentic Memory & Context Engineering Hackathon, Oct. 11 ‚Äî Push the boundaries of what you can build with MongoDB‚Äôs Atlas Vector Search and Voyage AI.*\n\nBoth OpenAI and Google have expanded their $5/mo AI plan to multiple countries.\n\nn8n has raised $180M at a $2.5B valuation, and Cursor is planning another round at $30B valuation.\n\n\n\n\nEnjoy this newsletter? Feel free to comment and share your thoughts. üëã\n\nFind me on X, Linkedin, or Instagram\n\nRead about me and ben‚Äôs bites\n\nüì∑ thumbnail creds: @keshavatearth,\n\n* marks sponsors that make this newsletter possible :)\nWanna partner with us? Last few slots left for the rest of the year.","enclosure":{"url":"https://substack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/images/d1dce3a7-83c0-485c-96d8-7e22c99896a9_460x276.png","length":"0","type":"image/jpeg"},"content":"by zooming out a little bit","contentSnippet":"by zooming out a little bit","guid":"https://www.bensbites.com/p/how-to-see-through-ai-marketing","isoDate":"2025-10-09T13:02:54.000Z","itunes":{}},"pairedItem":{"item":18}},{"json":{"title":"Thoughts from OpenAI DevDay","link":"https://www.bensbites.com/p/thoughts-from-openai-devday","pubDate":"Tue, 07 Oct 2025 13:31:01 GMT","content:encoded":"<p><em>The newsletter for the technically curious. Updates, tool reviews, and lay of the land from an exited founder turned investor and forever tinkerer.</em></p><p class=\"button-wrapper\" data-attrs=\"{&quot;url&quot;:&quot;https://www.bensbites.com/subscribe?&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Subscribe now&quot;,&quot;action&quot;:null,&quot;class&quot;:null}\" data-component-name=\"ButtonCreateButton\"><a class=\"button primary\" href=\"https://www.bensbites.com/subscribe?\"><span>Subscribe now</span></a></p><div><hr></div><p>Hey folks, I&#8217;ve just been at OpenAI Dev Day.</p><p>The event itself was phenomenal, great organisation. In terms of releases, there were two big themes:</p><ol><li><p>Add your apps to ChatGPT</p></li><li><p>Add ChatGPT to your apps </p></li></ol><p><strong><a href=\"https://openai.com/index/introducing-apps-in-chatgpt/\">Apps in ChatGPT</a></strong>, I think we all saw that coming. It renders a familiar UI based on the application you&#8217;re using (say, Figma) and syncs with your data using MCP. It feels native to ChatGPT vs. OpenAI&#8217;s previous attempts to make an app store (hello, Plugins &amp; GPT Store).</p><p>OpenAI promises discovery and monetisation for building on top of ChatGPT. But there&#8217;s a question about the future, will devs focus more on bundling components with MCP, so that AI can stitch together into an interface inside chat tools like ChatGPT or Claude, or building a website/app to be consumed by a human, which is very different? To me, it mimics how mobile apps became something you <em>need</em> to build now, but the web didn&#8217;t go away.</p><p>Then we have <strong><a href=\"https://openai.com/index/introducing-agentkit/\">AgentKit</a></strong> - A suite of tools to add a chat UI to your apps. There&#8217;s a visual workflow builder (like n8n or Zapier) called <strong><a href=\"https://platform.openai.com/agent-builder\">Agent Builder</a></strong>. And a <strong><a href=\"https://chatkit.studio/\">Widget Builder</a></strong> with ready-to-use components tailor-made for chat UIs. It&#8217;s for developer-adjacent roles, like a PM who can build a chatbot in a no-code UI and just hand the workflow_id to a dev or AI-generated code.</p><p>It&#8217;s not quite automating away repeated tasks (like Zapier); instead, it&#8217;s focusing on creating a chat-based experience on top of your product. But OpenAI can easily turn it into the former; they&#8217;re swallowing up the actual space in between any startups right now building anything with AI.</p><p>The OpenAI team typically say the same thing: &#8220;Well, the models are taking us wherever we&#8217;re going&#8221; and &#8220;models will keep getting better.&#8221; But that doesn&#8217;t mean ChatGPT needs a workflow builder. Fees like they&#8217;re capitalising on every opportunity enabled by the models improving. Also, they&#8217;re training the models to get better at certain things, like writing code, so it&#8217;s not uninformed.</p><p>Of course, there were the <a href=\"https://openai.com/devday/\">other updates</a> we expected:</p><ul><li><p>Sora 2 is now in the API. It&#8217;s cheaper than Veo 3&#8217;s API with better quality/controls.</p></li><li><p>Codex is generally available with a new SDK and Slack integration.</p></li><li><p>GPT-5 Pro is available in the API.</p></li><li><p>Cheaper, smaller models for voice-to-voice chat (<code>gpt-realtime-mini</code>) and image generation (<code>gpt-image-1-mini</code>).</p></li></ul><p>I saw some familiar faces: Swyx, Alessio from Latent Space, Alex from Thursday AI, Rowan from The Rundown, Greg from ARC-AGI, Dan Shipper. And Simon Willison sat next to me in a workshop, just coding away. He was like, <em>&#8220;Oh, they, they&#8217;ve launched this GPT Image Mini. It&#8217;s very cheap, they didn&#8217;t even mention it in the keynote,&#8221;</em> but he just discovered it and then did his <a href=\"https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/6/gpt-5-pro/\">pelican test for GPT-5-Pro</a> straight away. That was really cool, actually.</p><p>I also spoke to Greg Brockman, asking him, &#8220;Why is there no new thinking around GitHub and the whole development stack? I&#8217;m new to development, but writing code is no longer the hard part,&#8221; and he agreed with me. If you&#8217;re building in that space, reach out&#8212;I want to invest.</p><p>Also, <a href=\"https://luma.com/26lnt0gy\">come meet me IRL on 8th October in SF</a> and talk about Droids, ask the team questions, plus more free tokens :)</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://developers.googleblog.com/en/gemini-2-5-flash-image-now-ready-for-production-with-new-aspect-ratios/\">Nano-banana is generally available</a></strong> in the Gemini API. The stable version comes with support for 10 different aspect ratios and image-only output. Google DeepMind also shared the results of their new agent, <strong><a href=\"https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/introducing-codemender-an-ai-agent-for-code-security\">CodeMender</a></strong> (nice name). It&#8217;s built on top of Gemini Deep Think and can automatically patch critical software vulnerabilities.</p><p><strong>OpenAI built GPT for the masses. Brightwave built AI for professionals:</strong> full editability, traceability down to the sentence level, and 20x the compute. Their custom subagents can ingest 2000+ documents with zero loss of fidelity - try doing that with a consumer LLM. &#8594; <a href=\"https://lp.brightwave.io/research-platform/?utm_source=bensbites&amp;utm_medium=newsletter&amp;utm_campaign=107\">Your 7-day trial is waiting.</a>*</p><div><hr></div><h3><strong> </strong>&#127760;<strong> </strong>What I&#8217;m consuming</h3><ul><li><p><a href=\"https://a16zenterprise.substack.com/p/the-ai-application-spending-report\">Which apps are startups spending their AI budget</a> on (beyond GPUs)? The top 50 contains 4 vibe-coding and 10 creative AI tools, hinting they are here to stay.</p></li><li><p>Three paths for how AI changes <a href=\"https://jake.vision/blog/ai-for-science\">scientific discovery</a>.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://every.to/vibe-check/vibe-check-openai-devday-2025\">Vibe Check by Every</a> - OpenAI DevDay 2025.</p></li></ul><blockquote><p>If you&#8217;re looking for a tactical playbook on startup investing (did you know you can write $1k checks?), my friends at Angel Squad run a weekly newsletter called <strong>Small Bets</strong>. It&#8217;s one of the top investor newsletters in the space with 30k+ subscribers. If you&#8217;re interested in AI, you&#8217;ll enjoy it. Check it out &#8211; <a href=\"https://www.hustlefund.vc/small-bets\">subscribe here</a>.*</p></blockquote><div><hr></div><h3>&#9881;&#65039;  Tools and demos</h3><ul><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.assemblyai.com/?utm_source=bensbites&amp;utm_medium=newsletter_sponsor&amp;utm_campaign=toptools&amp;utm_content=voice_ai_100725\">AssemblyAI</a></strong> &#8211; Fast, accurate, scalable speech-to-text for the next generation of Voice AI apps.*</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://instant.bot/\">Instant.bot</a></strong> - Group chat with your own AI in Discord or a browser.</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.lindy.ai/blog/gaia-announcement\">Gaia by Lindy</a></strong> - Low-latency phone agent with memory that you can integrate with other tools, like a CRM.</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.perplexity.ai/comet\">Perplexity&#8217;s AI browser Comet</a></strong> is now available to everyone in the world</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://blog.reve.art/posts/reve-editing-model/\">Reve</a></strong> is a new startup training image models from scratch and making a product around them. Their latest image editing model is #4 on the image edit arena, but using it within their product experience feels like what Photoshop with AI should be.</p></li><li><p><strong><a href=\"https://conare.ai/\">Conare</a></strong> - Visual UI to manage context for Claude Code.</p></li></ul><div class=\"captioned-image-container\"><figure><a class=\"image-link image2 href=\"https://github.com/MaximeRivest/maivi\">Maivi</a> - Get a local voice-to-text model running on your device.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/safety-research/petri\">Petri</a> - Agent to audit model behaviours like sycophancy and deception. (<a href=\"https://www.anthropic.com/research/petri-open-source-auditing\">Anthropic&#8217;s blog</a>)</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://developers.googleblog.com/en/meet-jules-tools-a-command-line-companion-for-googles-async-coding-agent/\">Jules Tools</a> - Lightweight CLI to manage your tasks/trigger new tasks with Google Jules.</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://github.com/goodfire-ai/scribe\">Scribe by GoodFire AI</a> - Give Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini CLI agents access to Jupyter servers + notebooks. (Their goal here is enabling experimentation for AI safety research&#8212;<a href=\"https://www.goodfire.ai/blog/you-and-your-research-agent\">more in their blog</a>)</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><h3> &#128202; Charts I came across this week</h3><ul><li><p>Mercor AI, a hiring company that outsources data labelling for AI labs, released a new benchmark: <a href=\"https://mercor.com/apex\">AI Productivity Index (APEX)</a>. All the top models have roughly similar scores, except Opus 4.1, which scores way low here (vs. topping OpenAI&#8217;s similar <a href=\"https://openai.com/index/gdpval/\">GDPval</a>). href=\"https://partiful.com/e/SJZa5f8VCrcyTLMCvRsv?utm_campaign=battlefield1025&amp;utm_source=newsletter&amp;utm_medium=influencer&amp;utm_term=bens-bites\">Agentic Memory &amp; Context Engineering Hackathon, Oct. 11</a> &#8212; Push the boundaries of what you can build with MongoDB&#8217;s Atlas Vector Search and Voyage AI.*</p></li><li><p>Vercel is hosting a <a href=\"https://vercel.com/ship/ai\">one-day AI conference</a> on 23rd Oct in SF.</p></li><li><p>Medal, a company that allows you to capture and share video game clips, was getting $500M from OpenAI for their data. The deal fell through, and <a href=\"https://www.theinformation.com/articles/openai-offered-pay-500-million-startup-videogame-data\">Medal is now building a research lab of its own.</a></p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://supermemory.ai/blog/supermemory-raises-3-million-and-building-the-best-memory-engine-for-llms/\">Supermemory raised $3M</a> to build the best memory for LLMs and agents. (I&#8217;m an investor)</p></li><li><p><a href=\"https://openai.com/index/openai-amd-strategic-partnership/\">OpenAI is partnering with AMD</a> to deploy 6 GW of AMD GPUs over the next few years (and buy up to 10% of AMD stock).</p></li></ul><div><hr></div><div class=\"captioned-button-wrap\" data-attrs=\"{&quot;url&quot;:&quot;https://www.bensbites.com/p/thoughts-from-openai-devday?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&action=share&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Share&quot;}\" data-component-name=\"CaptionedButtonToDOM\"><div class=\"preamble\"><p class=\"cta-caption\">Enjoy this newsletter? Feel free to comment and share your thoughts. &#128075;</p><ul><li><p>Find me on <a href=\"https://x.com/bentossell/\">X</a>, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/ben-tossell-70453537/\">Linkedin</a>, or <a href=\"https://instagram.com/bentossell\">Instagram</a></p></li><li><p>Read <a href=\"https://bensbites.substack.com/about\">about me</a> and ben&#8217;s bites</p></li><li><p>&#128247; thumbnail creds: <a href=\"https://x.com/Keshavatearth\">@keshavatearth</a>,</p></li></ul><h6><em>* marks sponsors that make this newsletter possible :)</em></h6><h6><em>Wanna <a href=\"https://sponsor.bensbites.co/\">partner with us</a>? Last few slots left for the rest of the year.</em></h6><div><hr></div>","content:encodedSnippet":"The newsletter for the technically curious. Updates, tool reviews, and lay of the land from an exited founder turned investor and forever tinkerer.\nSubscribe now\n\n\nHey folks, I‚Äôve just been at OpenAI Dev Day.\nThe event itself was phenomenal, great organisation. In terms of releases, there were two big themes:\n\nAdd your apps to ChatGPT\n\nAdd ChatGPT to your apps \n\nApps in ChatGPT, I think we all saw that coming. It renders a familiar UI based on the application you‚Äôre using (say, Figma) and syncs with your data using MCP. It feels native to ChatGPT vs. OpenAI‚Äôs previous attempts to make an app store (hello, Plugins & GPT Store).\nOpenAI promises discovery and monetisation for building on top of ChatGPT. But there‚Äôs a question about the future, will devs focus more on bundling components with MCP, so that AI can stitch together into an interface inside chat tools like ChatGPT or Claude, or building a website/app to be consumed by a human, which is very different? To me, it mimics how mobile apps became something you need to build now, but the web didn‚Äôt go away.\nThen we have AgentKit - A suite of tools to add a chat UI to your apps. There‚Äôs a visual workflow builder (like n8n or Zapier) called Agent Builder. And a Widget Builder with ready-to-use components tailor-made for chat UIs. It‚Äôs for developer-adjacent roles, like a PM who can build a chatbot in a no-code UI and just hand the workflow_id to a dev or AI-generated code.\nIt‚Äôs not quite automating away repeated tasks (like Zapier); instead, it‚Äôs focusing on creating a chat-based experience on top of your product. But OpenAI can easily turn it into the former; they‚Äôre swallowing up the actual space in between any startups right now building anything with AI.\nThe OpenAI team typically say the same thing: ‚ÄúWell, the models are taking us wherever we‚Äôre going‚Äù and ‚Äúmodels will keep getting better.‚Äù But that doesn‚Äôt mean ChatGPT needs a workflow builder. Fees like they‚Äôre capitalising on every opportunity enabled by the models improving. Also, they‚Äôre training the models to get better at certain things, like writing code, so it‚Äôs not uninformed.\nOf course, there were the other updates we expected:\n\nSora 2 is now in the API. It‚Äôs cheaper than Veo 3‚Äôs API with better quality/controls.\n\nCodex is generally available with a new SDK and Slack integration.\n\nGPT-5 Pro is available in the API.\n\nCheaper, smaller models for voice-to-voice chat (gpt-realtime-mini) and image generation (gpt-image-1-mini).\n\nI saw some familiar faces: Swyx, Alessio from Latent Space, Alex from Thursday AI, Rowan from The Rundown, Greg from ARC-AGI, Dan Shipper. And Simon Willison sat next to me in a workshop, just coding away. He was like, ‚ÄúOh, they, they‚Äôve launched this GPT Image Mini. It‚Äôs very cheap, they didn‚Äôt even mention it in the keynote,‚Äù but he just discovered it and then did his pelican test for GPT-5-Pro straight away. That was really cool, actually.\nI also spoke to Greg Brockman, asking him, ‚ÄúWhy is there no new thinking around GitHub and the whole development stack? I‚Äôm new to development, but writing code is no longer the hard part,‚Äù and he agreed with me. If you‚Äôre building in that space, reach out‚ÄîI want to invest.\nAlso, come meet me IRL on 8th October in SF and talk about Droids, ask the team questions, plus more free tokens :)\nNano-banana is generally available in the Gemini API. The stable version comes with support for 10 different aspect ratios and image-only output. Google DeepMind also shared the results of their new agent, CodeMender (nice name). It‚Äôs built on top of Gemini Deep Think and can automatically patch critical software vulnerabilities.\nOpenAI built GPT for the masses. Brightwave built AI for professionals: full editability, traceability down to the sentence level, and 20x the compute. Their custom subagents can ingest 2000+ documents with zero loss of fidelity - try doing that with a consumer LLM. ‚Üí Your 7-day trial is waiting.*\n\n\n üåê What I‚Äôm consuming\n\nWhich apps are startups spending their AI budget on (beyond GPUs)? The top 50 contains 4 vibe-coding and 10 creative AI tools, hinting they are here to stay.\n\nThree paths for how AI changes scientific discovery.\n\nVibe Check by Every - OpenAI DevDay 2025.\n\n\nIf you‚Äôre looking for a tactical playbook on startup investing (did you know you can write $1k checks?), my friends at Angel Squad run a weekly newsletter called Small Bets. It‚Äôs one of the top investor newsletters in the space with 30k+ subscribers. If you‚Äôre interested in AI, you‚Äôll enjoy it. Check it out ‚Äì subscribe here.*\n\n\n‚öôÔ∏è  Tools and demos\n\nAssemblyAI ‚Äì Fast, accurate, scalable speech-to-text for the next generation of Voice AI apps.*\n\nInstant.bot - Group chat with your own AI in Discord or a browser.\n\nGaia by Lindy - Low-latency phone agent with memory that you can integrate with other tools, like a CRM.\n\nPerplexity‚Äôs AI browser Comet is now available to everyone in the world\n\nReve is a new startup training image models from scratch and making a product around them. Their latest image editing model is #4 on the image edit arena, but using it within their product experience feels like what Photoshop with AI should be.\n\nConare - Visual UI to manage context for Claude Code.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n ü•£ Dev dish\n\nMaivi - Get a local voice-to-text model running on your device.\n\nPetri - Agent to audit model behaviours like sycophancy and deception. (Anthropic‚Äôs blog)\n\nJules Tools - Lightweight CLI to manage your tasks/trigger new tasks with Google Jules.\n\nScribe by GoodFire AI - Give Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini CLI agents access to Jupyter servers + notebooks. (Their goal here is enabling experimentation for AI safety research‚Äîmore in their blog)\n\n\n\n üìä Charts I came across this week\n\nMercor AI, a hiring company that outsources data labelling for AI labs, released a new benchmark: AI Productivity Index (APEX). All the top models have roughly similar scores, except Opus 4.1, which scores way low here (vs. topping OpenAI‚Äôs similar GDPval). \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTop performing models across 4 professions covered by APEX\n\n\n üç¶ Afters\n\nAgentic Memory & Context Engineering Hackathon, Oct. 11 ‚Äî Push the boundaries of what you can build with MongoDB‚Äôs Atlas Vector Search and Voyage AI.*\n\nVercel is hosting a one-day AI conference on 23rd Oct in SF.\n\nMedal, a company that allows you to capture and share video game clips, was getting $500M from OpenAI for their data. The deal fell through, and Medal is now building a research lab of its own.\n\nSupermemory raised $3M to build the best memory for LLMs and agents. (I‚Äôm an investor)\n\nOpenAI is partnering with AMD to deploy 6 GW of AMD GPUs over the next few years (and buy up to 10% of AMD stock).\n\n\n\n\nEnjoy this newsletter? On to the news!People are just realizing that &#8220;Harness is the new app&#8221; but this was very clear early this year when we saw Claude and Gemini play pokemon. We&#8217;ve been talking about it since May but it&#8217;s gaining even more momentum now. Cursor is talking about improving their harness for Codex models and Poetic used a custom harness Gemini 3 Pro to get the best score on ARC-AGI 2.Google upgraded Deep Think with Gemini 3 for Ultra plan users ($250/mo). Shopify&#8217;s CTO and prev. Head of AI at Microsoft, Mikhail Parakhin, thinks the new version is better for coding something from scratch and notices more corner cases (and it&#8217;s faster), but still has some rough edges. You can now delegate tasks to Claude Code directly from Slack. I played around with Claude Code on the desktop app and it&#8217;s a nice interface for Claude as an Agent. I won&#8217;t be surprised if Claude app starts to look like that by default in 2026.Folks at HuggingFace got Claude Code and other CLIs to fine-tune an open model. It&#8217;s available as a skill. Here&#8217;s an idea for you to steal: make a local email processing app with a 3-7B model.Eliminate AI anxiety. Build with confidence. AI agents are the future&#8212;but centralized systems create costly risks. With Airia, prototype and orchestrate AI agents securely while creating a resilient, decentralized AI ecosystem for your organization. Get started today at airia.com*ps: GPT-5.2 is likely coming this week, and Google will launch its first AI glasses in 2026. &#127760; What I&#8217;m consumingYour experts won&#8217;t train your AI. You have to interview them.How I keep up with AI-generated PRs.Droid-maxxing - Pushing AI-assisted development to its limits.Google Illuminate is quietly becoming the best research tool I didn&#8217;t know I needed.Better ways to build self-improving agents - A recap of 2025 NeurIPS research papers.A profile of ChatGPT&#8217;s product chief, Nick Turley.Antropic&#8217;s resident philosopher, Amanda Askell, answers questions about AI.Stop juggling 5 APIs. AssemblyAI handles multilingual speech-to-text, speaker &amp; topic detection, and PII redaction in one stack. $0.15/hr, pay-as-you-go, no lock-in. Get free credits and start shipping features faster.*&#9881;&#65039; Tools and demosConcierge.ai - Engage &amp; convert inbound website visitors into qualified leads with a custom AI answer engine trained on your brand &amp; content.*Integrations by Parallel AI - Get fast and cheap search data right in Google Sheets, Zapier, n8n and more.Open Scouts - Open source web monitoring that alerts you when anything changes (ticket drops, restocks, news, etc).Private Notes - 100% offline AI note-taking iOS app (built with Droid).Stitch by Google Labs can now convert a design image generated by Nano Banana Pro into HTML. Another Google Labs product, Mixboard, also got some upgrades.You can now connect Replit Agent to remote MCP servers.Normal - Your team&#8217;s branding partner.&#129379; Dev DishClaude history explorer - Python CLI tool to explore, search and visualise your Claude Code conversation history.QMD by Tobi Lutke - On-device search engine for everything. A combination of BM25 full-text search, vector semantic search, and LLM re-ranking.&#128203; State of AI reportsOpenRouter released a &#8220;state of AI&#8221; report based on 100 trillion tokens used on their platform. Mostly focuses on how OSS models are used.Anthropic Interviewer - Anthropic interviewed 1,250 professionals about working with AI to map their emptions and expectaations. They are now opening it Claude users too (you should see a popup if you visit Claude on Web).The State of Enterprise AI by OpenAI - Haven&#8217;t got the chance to dig into this one but saw this chart. Top AI users use it much more than median users.&#127846; AftersSupabase is launching a white-label offering for platforms to help them provide fully managed database services. (I&#8217;m an investor)Axiom Prover solved 9/12 problems in the Putnam competition (often called as the hardest college-level math test).Rnj-1 by Essential AI is a strong 8B model, founder Ashish Vaswani is co-author of the Transformers paper.MosaicML&#8217;s (acq. by Databricks for $1.3B) founder, Naveen Rao, has a new company, Unconventional AI, raising $475M in seed funding at $4.5B valuation.Limitless (fka Rewind, working on AI device in pendant form) has been acquired by Meta.Enjoy this newsletter? The twins are chuffed to have a baby sister (although Max asked &#8220;where&#8217;s my boy&#8221; when we came home on Friday &#128514;). On to the news!People are just realizing that &#8220;Harness is the new app&#8221; but this was very clear early this year when we saw Claude and Gemini play pokemon. We&#8217;ve been talking about it since May but it&#8217;s gaining even more momentum now. Cursor is talking about improving their harness for Codex models and Poetic used a custom harness Gemini 3 Pro to get the best score on ARC-AGI 2.Google upgraded Deep Think with Gemini 3 for Ultra plan users ($250/mo). Shopify&#8217;s CTO and prev. Head of AI at Microsoft, Mikhail Parakhin, thinks the new version is better for coding something from scratch and notices more corner cases (and it&#8217;s faster), but still has some rough edges. You can now delegate tasks to Claude Code directly from Slack. I played around with Claude Code on the desktop app and it&#8217;s a nice interface for Claude as an Agent. I won&#8217;t be surprised if Claude app starts to look like that by default in 2026.Folks at HuggingFace got Claude Code and other CLIs to fine-tune an open model. It&#8217;s available as a skill. Here&#8217;s an idea for you to steal: make a local email processing app with a 3-7B model.Eliminate AI anxiety. Build with confidence. AI agents are the future&#8212;but centralized systems create costly risks. With Airia, prototype and orchestrate AI agents securely while creating a resilient, decentralized AI ecosystem for your organization. Get started today at airia.com*ps: GPT-5.2 is likely coming this week, and Google will launch its first AI glasses in 2026. &#127760; What I&#8217;m consumingYour experts won&#8217;t train your AI. You have to interview them.How I keep up with AI-generated PRs.Droid-maxxing - Pushing AI-assisted development to its limits.Google Illuminate is quietly becoming the best research tool I didn&#8217;t know I needed.Better ways to build self-improving agents - A recap of 2025 NeurIPS research papers.A profile of ChatGPT&#8217;s product chief, Nick Turley.Antropic&#8217;s resident philosopher, Amanda Askell, answers questions about AI.Stop juggling 5 APIs. AssemblyAI handles multilingual speech-to-text, speaker &amp; topic detection, and PII redaction in one stack. $0.15/hr, pay-as-you-go, no lock-in. Get free credits and start shipping features faster.*&#9881;&#65039; Tools and demosConcierge.ai - Engage &amp; convert inbound website visitors into qualified leads with a custom AI answer engine trained on your brand &amp; content.*Integrations by Parallel AI - Get fast and cheap search data right in Google Sheets, Zapier, n8n and more.Open Scouts - Open source web monitoring that alerts you when anything changes (ticket drops, restocks, news, etc).Private Notes - 100% offline AI note-taking iOS app (built with Droid).Stitch by Google Labs can now convert a design image generated by Nano Banana Pro into HTML. Another Google Labs product, Mixboard, also got some upgrades.You can now connect Replit Agent to remote MCP servers.Normal - Your team&#8217;s branding partner.&#129379; Dev DishClaude history explorer - Python CLI tool to explore, search and visualise your Claude Code conversation history.QMD by Tobi Lutke - On-device search engine for everything. A combination of BM25 full-text search, vector semantic search, and LLM re-ranking.&#128203; State of AI reportsOpenRouter released a &#8220;state of AI&#8221; report based on 100 trillion tokens used on their platform. Mostly focuses on how OSS models are used.Anthropic Interviewer - Anthropic interviewed 1,250 professionals about working with AI to map their emptions and expectaations. They are now opening it Claude users too (you should see a popup if you visit Claude on Web).The State of Enterprise AI by OpenAI - Haven&#8217;t got the chance to dig into this one but saw this chart. Top AI users use it much more than median users.&#127846; AftersSupabase is launching a white-label offering for platforms to help them provide fully managed database services. (I&#8217;m an investor)Axiom Prover solved 9/12 problems in the Putnam competition (often called as the hardest college-level math test).Rnj-1 by Essential AI is a strong 8B model, founder Ashish Vaswani is co-author of the Transformers paper.MosaicML&#8217;s (acq. by Databricks for $1.3B) founder, Naveen Rao, has a new company, Unconventional AI, raising $475M in seed funding at $4.5B valuation.Limitless (fka Rewind, working on AI device in pendant form) has been acquired by Meta.Enjoy this newsletter? Get free credits and start shipping features faster.*&#9881;&#65039; Tools and demosConcierge.ai - Engage &amp; convert inbound website visitors into qualified leads with a custom AI answer engine trained on your brand &amp; content.*Integrations by Parallel AI - Get fast and cheap search data right in Google Sheets, Zapier, n8n and more.Open Scouts - Open source web monitoring that alerts you when anything changes (ticket drops, restocks, news, etc).Private Notes - 100% offline AI note-taking iOS app (built with Droid).Stitch by Google Labs can now convert a design image generated by Nano Banana Pro into HTML. Another Google Labs product, Mixboard, also got some upgrades.You can now connect Replit Agent to remote MCP servers.Normal - Your team&#8217;s branding partner.&#129379; Dev DishClaude history explorer - Python CLI tool to explore, search and visualise your Claude Code conversation history.QMD by Tobi Lutke - On-device search engine for everything. A combination of BM25 full-text search, vector semantic search, and LLM re-ranking.&#128203; State of AI reportsOpenRouter released a &#8220;state of AI&#8221; report based on 100 trillion tokens used on their platform. Mostly focuses on how OSS models are used.Anthropic Interviewer - Anthropic interviewed 1,250 professionals about working with AI to map their emptions and expectaations. They are now opening it Claude users too (you should see a popup if you visit Claude on Web).The State of Enterprise AI by OpenAI - Haven&#8217;t got the chance to dig into this one but saw this chart. Top AI users use it much more than median users.&#127846; AftersSupabase is launching a white-label offering for platforms to help them provide fully managed database services. (I&#8217;m an investor)Axiom Prover solved 9/12 problems in the Putnam competition (often called as the hardest college-level math test).Rnj-1 by Essential AI is a strong 8B model, founder Ashish Vaswani is co-author of the Transformers paper.MosaicML&#8217;s (acq. by Databricks for $1.3B) founder, Naveen Rao, has a new company, Unconventional AI, raising $475M in seed funding at $4.5B valuation.Limitless (fka Rewind, working on AI device in pendant form) has been acquired by Meta.Enjoy this newsletter? You can now delegate tasks to Claude Code directly from Slack. I played around with Claude Code on the desktop app and it&#8217;s a nice interface for Claude as an Agent. I won&#8217;t be surprised if Claude app starts to look like that by default in 2026.Folks at HuggingFace got Claude Code and other CLIs to fine-tune an open model. It&#8217;s available as a skill. Here&#8217;s an idea for you to steal: make a local email processing app with a 3-7B model.Eliminate AI anxiety. Build with confidence. AI agents are the future&#8212;but centralized systems create costly risks. With Airia, prototype and orchestrate AI agents securely while creating a resilient, decentralized AI ecosystem for your organization. AssemblyAI handles multilingual speech-to-text, speaker &amp; topic detection, and PII redaction in one stack. $0.15/hr, pay-as-you-go, no lock-in. Get free credits and start shipping features faster.*&#9881;&#65039; Tools and demosConcierge.ai - Engage &amp; convert inbound website visitors into qualified leads with a custom AI answer engine trained on your brand &amp; content.*Integrations by Parallel AI - Get fast and cheap search data right in Google Sheets, Zapier, n8n and more.Open Scouts - Open source web monitoring that alerts you when anything changes (ticket drops, restocks, news, etc).Private Notes - 100% offline AI note-taking iOS app (built with Droid).Stitch by Google Labs can now convert a design image generated by Nano Banana Pro into HTML. Another Google Labs product, Mixboard, also got some upgrades.You can now connect Replit Agent to remote MCP servers.Normal - Your team&#8217;s branding partner.&#129379; Dev DishClaude history explorer - Python CLI tool to explore, search and visualise your Claude Code conversation history.QMD by Tobi Lutke - On-device search engine for everything. A combination of BM25 full-text search, vector semantic search, and LLM re-ranking.&#128203; State of AI reportsOpenRouter released a &#8220;state of AI&#8221; report based on 100 trillion tokens used on their platform. Mostly focuses on how OSS models are used.Anthropic Interviewer - Anthropic interviewed 1,250 professionals about working with AI to map their emptions and expectaations. They are now opening it Claude users too (you should see a popup if you visit Claude on Web).The State of Enterprise AI by OpenAI - Haven&#8217;t got the chance to dig into this one but saw this chart. Top AI users use it much more than median users.&#127846; AftersSupabase is launching a white-label offering for platforms to help them provide fully managed database services.
